Creepy underwater horror flick. Ahead of its time.
As directed by Jack Arnold, the film suffers from silly stretches of dialogue and wooden acting, but the underwater footage is still beautiful, and Adams radiates a strong, sexy screen presence.
Very neat
The routine story is mightily improved by Arnold's sure sense of atmospheric locations and by the often sympathetic portrait of the monster.
This adventure has no depth.
Imbued with great atmosphere by director Jack Arnold, the film is genuinely frightening, but also elicits a certain amount of pathos for the creature.
The underwater sequences were excellently shot by Havens, and the make-up for the half man, half fish was a masterful creation by Bud Westmore and Jack Keven.

Jack Arnold has a flair for this sort of thing, and if there really is anything frightening about a man dressed up in a rubber suit with zippers where the gills ought to be, Arnold comes close to finding it.
Jack Arnold's direction has done a firstrate job developing chills and suspense, and James C. Havens rates a good credit for his direction of the underwater sequences.
The beats of the film are like overused sandpaper, too worn down and tattered to have more than a passing effect.
What distinguished Jack Arnold's pictures from mutant spinoffs/knockoffs is even more imperative to sci-fi today than it was in 1954: wonderment.
When I was a kid, this was the movie monster I wanted to be.
Okay, it's just a guy in a rubber suit. Even people in the 1950's weren't afraid of this so-called monster. But, there's some camp value to this on-the-water and under-the-water adventure.
It makes for solid horror-thrill entertainment.
The whole thing is ultimately just a '50s B-movie, but it's hard to imagine what they could have done to make it a better one.
This is a pulp classic with good reason.
This is certainly one of the most fondly remembered of the science fiction films of the 1950s.

Along comes one of those tedious, topeed expeditions, in a battered white boat, and the "Gill-Man" is chased, photographed, speared, half-asphyxiated, and screamed at. No wonder he commits murder (five of them).
The boys at Universal were on a fanciful binge, putting on an enjoyable show in the water, something less in dry-dock.
Short on science, the picture's long enough on excitement, strongly recalling the hit Beast from 20,000 Fathoms.
A prehistoric man shaped fish falls in love with screaming Julia Adams in an Amazon backwater, but his courtship is a failure. So is the movie.
There are some effective underwater scenes; otherwise script and direction are commonplace.
The subject matter has been handled in a way that makes for a maximum of suspense and with an eye toward satisfying those who seek horrific chills and thrills.
It's horribly dated, the acting's lousy, the 3D effects are worthless and the monster is a man in a rubber suit. Yet Creature from the Black Lagoon remains one of the all-time classic monster movies.
Its ambiguously gay villain notwithstanding, Fire and Ice just doesn't hold the weight, either visually or thematically, that its creators probably hoped it would.
It fully conjures a universe that other movies had to infer with cheap sets and silly costumes.
A classic style, dressed up in irony. [Full Review in Spanish]
This animated fantasy from Ralph Bakshi and Frank Frazetta is just a half-step above garbage, despite some cool elements.
The 40-minute car chase ... is one wild ride. The rest of the film, however, is sorely lacking.
The car wrecks pile up to boredom before the end.
Halicki may know car chases, but he doesn't really know anything about dramatic filmmaking
It's a pity that it had to descend into such routine carnage.

Amateurish, badly acted and shot on the cheap (many sequences don't even have sync sound), this cult item features a 40-minute car chase (almost half the film's running time) that's nothing short of breathtaking.

... perhaps the ultimate drive-in car chase movie. If that sounds like a backhanded compliment, then you don't know the sheer visceral thrill of a great tire squealing, chassis-slamming, speed demon piece of auto outlaw cinema.
A campy Corman classic. Drink some beers and have fun with it!
Aside from all this surface nonsense, there's something interesting about the film (perhaps all the emphasis on eating and mouths).
Whether the film fully lives up to its reputation is another matter, but there is no doubt that The Little Shop of Horrors has earned its small place in cult movie history.
Before inspiring all of the catchy musical numbers, Corman's film remains an absurd, slapstick comedy with a sharp mix of stark depression.
It's the funniest but most real-looking horror film ever made.

Shocks come from the way in which Romero repeatedly presents a clichd situations in which we think we know what's going on, only for Romero to pull out the rug from underneath, thereby producing a greater shock.
Gets under your skin and burrows into your blood and psyche.
reinvented the American horror film
There is a resounding lack of sentimentality that cuts through the death and chaos, as a desperate bunch of people fight to stay alive.
This disc is done right!
I can't underrate its intangible ability to bypass my rationale and lunge straight at my subconscious. When it's really cooking, it's the scariest film I've ever seen.
It's the anticipation of horrible scenarios that makes the film work so well.
A spare, disturbing classic.
This film managed to successfully mesh the concepts of flesh-eating zombies, isolation, and global panic realized on a claustrophobic and intimate scale.
The dialogue and background music sound hollow, as if they had been recorded in an empty swimming pool, and the wobbly camera seems to have a fetishist's interest in hands.
Landmark horror film somewhat blunted by bad acting.
Ainda hoje permanece como um dos melhores do gnero.
Night of the Living Dead happens to rank squarely with the greatest films ever made, period.
Sorry, but it really isn't that scary in this day and age.
Maybe the best movie ever made in Pittsburgh.
The latest "Ultimate Edition" features a digitally colourised version as well as an audio commentary by Mike Nelson.
A tightly-edited, claustrophobically-framed horror film that retains, along with its relevance, its ability to startle and appall.
The grandaddy of them all. Created a whole new genre'
A doozie.
One of the best films ever made, and possibly the most influential horror movie of all time.
Chuckle, if you can, during the first few minutes; because after that laughter catches in the throat as the clammy hand of terror tightens its grip.
This is horror at its most probing, subversive and socially aware, with a truly harrowing ending that reveals the dangers of misdirected fear and prejudice.
A quarter of a century old and it is still absolutely terrifying.

George Romero's remarkably assured debut, made on a shoestring, about a group of people barricaded inside a farmhouse while an army of flesh-eating zombies roams the countryside, deflates all genre clichs.
Over its short, furious course, the picture violates so many strong taboos -- cannibalism, incest, necrophilia -- that it leaves audiences giddy and hysterical.
I felt real terror in that neighborhood theater last Saturday afternoon. I saw kids who had no resources they could draw upon to protect themselves from the dread and fear they felt.
Seldom have so many pundit parses and public praises owed so much to so little as in the case of the career-launching 'Night of the Living Dead.'
There's a brute force in Night of the Living Dead that catches one in the throat.
Arguably the greatest horror film ever made - and one of the greatest in any genre - 'Night' is also the ultimate B-movie.
This little seat-of-the-pants regional production chewed up and spit out taboos like raw meat in a feral feeding frenzy.
George Romero set a new standard for horror with this low-budget opus.
Although pic's basic premise is repellent -- recently dead bodies are resurrected and begin killing human beings in order to eat their flesh -- it is in execution that the film distastefully excels.
One of the most nightmarish films ever made, and one that's still hard to laugh off today.
Romero saw the enemy, and they are the zombie masses among us. There is nowhere safe to hide.
The racial subtext spoke volumes in 1968. Once the zombies start knocking, only a fool would cling to segregation.

Night of the Living Dead (1968) was director George Romero's most notable genre-defining, classic zombie horror film -- it quickly became his calling card, and was responsible for making him influentially known as the Master of the modern 'zombie film'
Oft-copied zombie classic is still intense and gory.

"Night of the Living Dead" became a seminal film without being a particularly good one. It nudged horror movies away from creepy-but-family-friendly into adult films featuring gruesome violence and nihilistic overtones.
The original and the best.

It's a virulent portrait of an America in flux and decay, from the flag billowing near the graveyard at the start to its disturbing depiction of a lynch-mob mentality. But Night also transcends its period through sheer intensity.
It's pitch perfect in writing, mood, and scares, and still holds up to scrutiny, no matter how harsh.
Subjects us to the kind of unrelenting nightmare we only wish we could wake up from.
If [Romero's] original vision of the undead looks dulled by today's standards, his embedded political commentary on racism feels just as sharp.
Director George A Romero redefined the meaning of horror for fear-sated audiences in the 1960s with this seminal classic.
Carve[s] open the guts of American culture, using violence and even the horror genre itself as a tool rather than an end.
The immediate, quasi-documentary feel, a result of budgetary constraints, actually served the film's horror, jolting audiences because it all seemed just a little too real.
All in all, Night of the Living Dead is obviously just as marvellous as it's always been.
A landmark of American cinema. Intentional or not, the film's sociopolitical content remains as potent as ever.

Night of the Living Dead (1968) is the first genuinely modern horror movie, shot more like a documentary of the apocalypse than the Gothic horrors that defined the sixties, and it bled right into the fabric of the culture.
Combined with Romero's political commentary is a cinematic aesthetic that arguably outstrips its sequels in both craft and effectiveness.

What's truly remarkable is how, after half a century and an uncountable number of zombie films, novels, comics, TV shows, and video games, you can watch the original Night of the Living Dead and it still feels fresh and terrifying.
It's tame of course by today's standards, but that, combined with he cynical racial component, was viewed as an all-out attack on "civilized" American society in general.
A slightly tacky horror picture which makes quite an impact; partly, I suspect, by ingeniously playing off its own limitations.
The movie remains unsettling after all these years because of its bleak simplicity.
Romero conjures moments of eeriness and dread throughout, keeping the lighting low and the special effects to a minimum, though there will be blood, fire, cannibalism and a great deal of death.

Night of the Living Dead is a revolutionary moment in American independent cinema, a film that inspired countless of filmmakers to pick up a camera and attempt their dream with nothing more than a handful of friends, a shoestring budget, and a vision.
...there's a strong element of social satire in this low-budget horror movie, and racism is not Romero's only target...
Night of the Living Dead was so far ahead of its time, Hollywood is still trying to catch up.
The simple setup, stark black-and-white photography, limited resources, and eerie music give the film an effectiveness not often found in such minimalist ventures.
This was an American horror movie, so it needed no English accents or familiar character actors. It was grim and unflinching...
I love how the black and white cinematography adds to the mood

review_content: Shoot 'em up gangsters, Prohibition era, via Roger Corman.

Corman is adept at creating human moments between the plot points, reminding us of the little guys caught up in the war and the human cost of the violence...
It's a cool, violent film, romantic in a disciplined, disenchanted way about its battling gangsters.
At the end of this nonsense, to be sure, there is a massacre to brighten things up a little. But then the pall sets in again.
The carefully stylized violence and reconstruction of that era comes off very well.
Anthology horror worthy of a stormy night.

The film should appeal to fans of the weird and those with a campy sense of humor more than those who are more serious about drama and Poe.
A lavish-looking, stylish piece of work.

Walter Hill's vibrant 1979 adaptation of Sol Yurick's 1965 novel - based loosely on an ancient Greek story called "Anabasis" - is a classic cinematic record of New York City circa 1979.

If you've never seen this film, I can't recommend it highly enough. It's definitely in my TOP 5 of "all-time greatest movies."

Although Stone may be pleasing to some eyes, she's pretty small in the saddle here -- just an innocuous gender twist on the reluctant cowboy hero. And her story of hellbent revenge is about as compelling as a 30-second fragrance commercial.
As preposterous as the plot was, there was never a line of Hackman dialogue that didn't sound as if he believed it. The same can't be said, alas, for Sharon Stone...
It's a mess, and one that even the pickled cowboys behind me found yawningly tedious, and that's not something I ever thought I'd be saying about a Sam Raimi movie with the word "dead" in the title.
You get lots of clothes here, but no emperor.

Raimi's choice to give the film a comic book-like aura of mingled camp and grit makes for some fitfully energetic and entertaining moments, but it's not enough to overcome The Quick and the Dead's primary fault.
As it is, the film's more off-the-wall tendencies -- and there are plenty -- just seem ill at ease, if not completely out of place.
Without a real focus on Raimi's satirical sensibilities and acrobatic camera tricks, it's just a less-than-mediocre knock-off of Eastwood's oeuvre.
Sam Raimi's over-the-top homage/sendup of old westerns actually succeeds in making Sharon Stone a believable gunslinger.
Perhaps another director could have gotten both tribute and parody to work together; in Raimi's hands, they instead cast doubt upon each other.
There should be a law that, if you're going to make a terribly clichd film, then you at least have to do something original in it. The Quick and the Dead exemplifies this.
Rarely dull, it is not noticeably compelling either, and as the derivative offshoot of a derivative genre, it inevitably runs out of energy well before any of its hotshots runs out of bullets.
The whole film has tremendous visual style, and the frequent bursts of violence are delivered with a clever and often hilarious use of special effects.
What Raimi can't find is a center. He hankers for us to giggle at the brutal archetypes he's parodying and to warm to them, too. It won't wash, pardner.
Another one of those movies meant for movie freaks.
Even when the script for The Quick and the Dead runs out of surprises, which is very early, director Sam Raimi keeps the action fast and funny, though he falters when he strains for seriousness.
This film is wonderfully directed by Sam Raimi, who makes every shot pop up. From the gripping opening scene to the weird finale, every scene is full of Raimi's great visual style.

Mr. Raimi is limited by a sketch mentality, which means his jokes tend to be over long before his films end. But his tastes for visual mischief and crazy, ill-advised homage can still make for sly, sporadic fun.
Awesome western. Raimi's technique heightens the standard gunfight drama.
See it for yourself - surprising
Stylish Raimi western is violent, unpredictable.
Raimi's gimmicky but endlessly inventive direction gives it plenty of gas, and the excellent cast takes it the rest of the way.
Sharon Stone misses the mark on this one.
A deadpan black comedy, Sam Raimi's fast-paced movie looks and sounds like a Leone oater but more so.
Raimi's movie borrows heavily from classic spaghetti westerns, but Raimi has a style of his own, and plenty of it.

Sam Raimi does a lot of interesting things in The Quick and the Dead and Sharon Stone plays a convincing female gunfighter, but the one-horse plot with no subplots to generate additional interest becomes a drag.
The plot of this low-camp revenge thriller is little more than an excuse to line up one badass cowboy (or girl) opposite another and let the eyeball-to-eyeball fireworks fly.

Too manufactured and 'Hollywood' to elicit any real emotion.

Loaded with potential, it's puzzlingly overblown and distant, as if its huge budget were an albatross around its neck.

An abbreviated and shallow epic that comes off like an over-produced and dead-serious episode of the campy cult TV show Xena: Warrior Princess.
This stinker barks. It has been fermenting for a couple of years as the creative minds behind it continued to cut, recut then cut again, trying to make steak out of ground beef.
Director John McTiernan did this long before The Hunt for Red October and he would be wise to leave it off his resume.

"Warrior" is simply a mess. It does, however, offer the sight of Antonio Banderas (in eyeliner, no less) struggling to portray an Arab soldier, which must be one of the most curious casting choices since Demi Moore played a Puritan.
. Seeing "The 13th Warrior" is like wishing for light at the end of a long dark tunnel, when we both know nothing is really there.
It's little more than a shoddy string of action-movie cliches.
With the possible exception of the action sequences and the very occasionally imaginative set design, it's awful.
The cheese flows fast and furious from the screen.
Much blood. Much mud. Not enough camp.
The 13th Warrior indulges in enough grubby histrionics and costume-adventure clichs to give you fifth-grade flashbacks.
Ludicrously bad!
The film falls short of its goal to find a distinct personality and never attains the suspension of belief required of genre films like Conan or 7th Voyage of Sinbad.
It's not a good sign when what the filmmakers seemingly intended to be a straightforward action film leaves the viewers saying, 'Huh?'
A mud-stained, blood-soaked and completely useless movie.
Banderas puts in a decent turn, but it's Norwegian newcomer Dennis Storhoi who steals the show; his charming, effortless performance shows both the perils and pleasures of being a Viking.
The 13th Warrior reeks so badly of melodrama and poor acting that it carries a worst scent than a canine's least appetizing residue.
The actual story is really nothing more than a continuous and extremely gory battle scene, filled with missing heads, hacked-off limbs, and pools of blood.
Stupefyingly horrendous.
The 13th Warrior contains the raw materials of an offbeat adventure, but fails to achieve the rousing mood or narrative glory of a grand epic.
The 13th Warrior is simply without thrills and excitement.
The film feels as hollow as empty armor and slightly hackneyed.
Murky, all - but - impossible to follow battle sequences.
The film feels as if it had a bad run through the editing room.
The whole mess is often too busy to get down to business.
Funny, although it doesn't mean to be.
Michael Crichton is quite a character; his films could use a little.
With a budget said to be more than $100 million, it displays a lot of cash on the screen, but little thought.

If the juiciest bouts of professional wrestling on television leave you feeling unfulfilled and pining for the primal howls of fight - to - the - death combat, The 13th Warrior just might be the answer to your prayers.
An exhilarating 100 minutes!
It falls short where it counts: in the final confrontation.
There is no teller here. Its scenes are full of darkness. Its words have the sound of madness shouted in the wind.

The film is based on Eaters of the Dead, possibly the worst novel Michael Crichton has ever written, and this film isn't even a passable adaptation.
Although the subject matter is not too pleasant and the gore is turned up to 11, Crichton's film is an excellent Nordic war story.
An entertaining and serviceable adaptation. Dennis Storhoi delivers an awesome performance. Weak aspects of story made up for by great action.
It harks back to the late 1950s when people actually made movies about Vikings and other seafaring heroes named Sinbad and Jason.
The film is fascinating to watch, but I can hardly say what it's about, other than people killing each other.
If you're in the mood to watch heads, arms and other appendages getting chopped off, this movie is for you.
At its best, this achieves the beauty and grandeur of a Kurosawa epic -- at its worst, however, it feels like a Python remake of The Vikings.
Shelved for over a year and probably heavily edited, it's better than it could have been.
Mr. Crichton may have found the perfect venue for his particular brand of character underdevelopment.
Michael Crichton's story is underdeveloped and narrow in range, resulting in a tale more curious for its odd confluence of elements than for their edifying deployment.
Jerry Goldsmith's rousing score exhibits more personality than any of the actors--or anything else in the film, for that matter.
"The 13th Warrior" is a brazen attempt to brand Antonio Banderas as an A-lister with a C-grade script. Failure attends.
Exciting battle sequences, intriguing period costumes, fascinating cinematography, and stirring background music contribute to the epic nature of 'The 13th Warrior.'
Akira Kurosawa's brilliant samurai movies -- especially 1957's Throne of Blood -- are a visual influence. But the script lacks the dignity that infuses Kurosawa's equally blood-thirsty characters.
To the film's credit its topic supplies a wealth of material, philosophy, and entertainment -- and victim to it, A Galaxy Far Far Away meanders in the wide, overwhelming scope of its course.
Triumph the Insult Comic Dog did a far better job - and actually a more sensitive job - with the fans waiting outside for the start of Episode II.
As Luke once said, what a piece of junk.
Yimou's overdone compositions lend a cartoonish quality to the proceedings that sap it of most of its punch.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: This exaggeration of human behavior, with farcical humor based on a flow of ironies and the wages of greed, does its source no favors.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: ...Another visual triumph from the celebrated Chinese director, but quirky eye candy of superficial comic-book proportions can go only so far with art-house crowds.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: Photographer Zhao Xiaoding captures the sunsets, his sun turning the sandy hills of the desert a mysterious red.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: When did Zhang Yimou start acting like Jean-Pierre Jeunet?
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: Those with a higher tolerance for bumptious jestering -- from a yipping and mincing Xiao, or Cheng Ye as a bucktoothed jelly-belly -- may, however, cry Masterpiece.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: Zhang Yimou has paid the Coen brothers the highest compliment one filmmaker can pay another.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: From one great director to another, a Woman, a Gun and a Noodle Shop pays tribute to the Coens by improving their earlier immature work.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: So this is how you follow up the Olympic opening ceremonies!
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: Where the Coen Brothers' film was darkly humorous, Yimou goes for a broad comedy that may not translate to American audiences (crossed eyes and buck teeth used for laughs, for example) and his pace seems draggy.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: Better you should go rent Blood Simple and see what it's all about.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: Zhang brings little else to the story besides an improved color palette and bad comic timing.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: A fascinating curiosity piece for Coen fans, but ... every performance and every scene pales next to its inspiration.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: Mr. Zhang uncovers the primal, mythic intensity of the story and also changes the tone of its essential nihilism.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: Lacks the Coen brothers' precision, their diabolical game-board cleverness. It's a remake in shaggy outline only.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: The film is all over the place, really, until the plot kicks in, at which point Zhang hits the dimmer and plunges everyone into darkness, even a pair of characters seemingly on hand purely for comic relief.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: That Zhang stages the story as a broad, absurdist comedy, as opposed to the Coens' dark, brooding drama, is another telling point of departure.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: The stars of the show, ultimately, are Zhao Xiaoding's gorgeous cinematography, Tao Jing's evocative sound design and Yimou's choice of otherworldly locations.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: The masterly use of majestic landscapes and expert lensing...make this a beautiful film to watch but the combination of bloody drama and silly comedy take me out of the moment.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: Whereas the Coens worked with a shoestring budget and emphasized a deadpan sense of humor, Zhang pours on expensive special effects whenever the opportunity for large-scale slapstick presents itself.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: Zhang needs to reconnect with the sensibility -- fierce, principled, humanistic -- that made him one of China's finest film artists.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: A Woman, a Gun and a Noodle Shop is an easy film to watch and admire, but a hard one to connect with, let alone love.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: An odd, oddly likable hybrid, "A Woman, a Gun and a Noodle Shop" is a tribute from Zhang Yimou, arguably the greatest filmmaker of his generation in China...
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: For the Coens, the parable of lust and greed suggested that nothing was certain but death and the battle of the sexes. For Yimou, it's a ghost story of sexual lust and money lust.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: Zhang's version dries out the original's sultriness, trades humid night for arid day, and strains for slapstick.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: A Woman, a Gun and a Noodle Shop is 95 minutes of not right.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: There are lots of vertiginous high angles and sweeping wide-screen vistas, but they never congeal into a compelling atmosphere.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: There are enough pratfalls and purely physical comedy bits here to populate a Keystone Kops/Three Stooges double feature. While they're intermittently amusing, they don't really feel consistent with the rest of what Zhang is doing with the film.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: In Blood Simple, the cascading confusions lead to moral solitude and death; in Noodle Shop, the foremost misunderstanding involves a character who mistakes the phrase 'must die' for 'moose die.'
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: Its visual brightness and tonal goofiness are far from the darkness of the Coens' noir, and overall not nearly as successful.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: Ever watch a Coen brothers film and think, "Gee, this would be a lot better if the characters had buck teeth and fell down a lot?"
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: The movie soon devolves into nothing more than a fairly close-to-the-vest adaptation.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: Don't attempt to remake a Coen brothers movie, especially if you plan to turn the thing into a bizarre concoction of melodrama and slapstick comedy.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: Zhang's early films, especially 1990's Ju Dou, mixed noir-style plotlines with stunning cinematography, and Woman, Gun nicely sets its characters' vividly colored costumes against its barren, hilly landscape.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: The Coens' Loren Visser (M. Emmet Walsh) is cold blooded, but to see the new hitman's method of silent murder will unveil the real noirish heart of darkness.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: This clunker by director Zhang Yimou purports to be a remake of Blood Simple but looks more like a bad imitation of Terry Gilliam.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: The Coens' original Gothic film noir, wound as tight as a Texas rattlesnake, unravels to the point of amateur slapstick. Though the exterior shots look like Sedona on acid, it's still not worth the, um, trip.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: It takes real chutzpah to challenge the Coen brothers when it comes to stylization in movies, but Chinese director Zhang Yimou has done just that.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: Most will find Noodle all wet--limp, if you will--in Yimou's apparent choice to remake Blood Simple in the style of Raising Arizona.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: An uneasy mix of Coen-style laughs (particularly evident in the big comic close-ups) and Zhang's majestic imagery (in one shot the couple's divorce papers shatter into a burst of confetti).
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun)

review_content: What sounds as though it ought to be delicious winds up, instead, a soggy noodle.

review_content: The main problem with A Woman, a Gun and a Noodle Shop has less to do with its fidelity to the Coen brothers' 1984 original than with director Zhang Yimou's own incompatibility with the material.

review_content: A Woman, a Gun and a Noodle Shop is great to look at. It's just not much fun to watch.

review_content: It's called A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop, and, although the woman and the gun are bores, the noodles are cool, I guess.

review_content: A whimsical but fizzled experiment.

review_content: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop is a tipsy wedding of low hijinks and tiptoe-tense suspense stretches.

review_content: Unfortunately, movies about banal people are often banal themselves.
Among the great American crime movies, 1973's Badlands stands alone.

minimizes the inherent sensationalism of its material with a deliberately slow pace, and Malick constantly undercuts the potential thrill of on-screen violence by rendering it awkward, vicious, and ugly
Badlands (1973) is the remarkable and impressive directorial debut from twenty-nine year old director Terrence Malick (who also scripted and produced the film).
I can't pin down the exact moment I realized that I was watching something special.
Terrence Malick is truly a one of a kind filmmaker.
Sheen works an abundance of meaning into a very small space, so we at least recognize this doomed, erstwhile child as all too human, and appropriately dangerous.
Badlands is an arena for apathy, both in regard to the characters' depictions and their subjective emotions.
A fantastic debut by Malick, who has never lived up to the promise since.
Kit is played by Martin Sheen, in one of the great modern film performances.
Malick's dreamlike murder story is still haunting.
Terrific, chilling debut by Sheen.
A groundbreaking seminal folk tale about aimless youths.
Stunning.

Like Bonnie and Clyde, Badlands could be seen as a poetic ballad or folktale, but unlike that film, it doesn't romanticize its protags, instead using distancing devices such as Sissy Spacek's affectless narration.
Bonnie and Clyde without the Freud, but with a darker, more incomprehensible underbelly.
Terrence Malick introduced his odd yet highly compelling filmmaking style in this 1973 feature.
Written, produced and directed by Terrence Malick, pic is his first feature and it's an impressive debut.
Makes for classic, troubling yet fascinating cinema.
The superb performances from Sheen and Spacek are as memorable as Malick's vision of something akin to hell.
The unique, lilting music would subsequently crop up in True Romance, though Tarantino's generation has yet to dethrone Badlands as the most haunting of all couple-on-the-run movies.
An unmissable reissue for Terrence Malick's gorgeous and troubling debut.
Terrence Malick's thriller Badlands (1973), is rightly revered as one of the most astonishing debuts in cinema. Its reissue is a wonderful chance to discover why.
Terrence Malick's first masterpiece. Essential viewing.
This first, magnificent, outpouring of the sporadic genius of cinema's equivalent to JD Salinger, Terrence Malick, still seems terrifically modern.
Achingly evocative of a time when Hollywood had the courage to invest in complex and morally ambiguous films and an indisputable masterpiece of American cinema.
Days of Heaven put Terrence Malick's intuitions into cogent form, but this is where his art begins.
Malick's film, full of striking cutaways to the burning-sun horizon and the harsh landscape's solitary creatures, comes to operate at an overpoweringly chilling remove.
...the first of Malick's many screen Edens, all of which inevitably come to a violent end.
Incredibly beautiful, of course (you may have heard that Malick movies are famous for their landscapes), but it's not "just" beautiful.
In his debut, Terrence Malick is an uncanny creator of pearlescent forms, a very stark balladeer, Mark Twain's coolly ferocious heir
Malick has come to be known and revered as a cinematic poet and philosopher, as a filmmaker who explores big ideas, but in Badlands in particular he also shows a knack for off-kilter humor.
One of Malick's most resonant notions in Badlands is that everyone confronts mortality in his or her own way.
It's a testament to Bruce Greenwood's acting that Adan never becomes entirely as insufferable as the words that come out of his mouth.

In the fall of 1973, one could see signposts of cinema's future in Mean Streets and The Exorcist, yet with this youthful pair of proto-indie dreamers, Malick was paving a whole new road. It turned out to be the path most traveled.
This tender treatment does nothing to alleviate the horror of the atrocities committed.
The movie is just as free, experimental, and unsure of itself as its main characters are, and thus fits like a glove.
[VIDEO ESSAY] Terrence Malick's self-penned feature debut is a haunting road movie pitched in '50s Americana. The film's razor-sharp tone of poetic irony is unique.
If a portion of American cinema is going to remain devoted to violence, it could learn a lot by revisiting Malick's thoughtfulness.
A masterly exercise in ironic narration, and of a director so wholly in command of the rhetoric of his medium.
Malick's love and respect for the natural world as it frames and moves characters is palpable and on full display, the film heightened by superb performances and Malick's incredible direction.
Angry young white men.

Everyone concerned with Badlands has my admiration -- Martin Sheen and Sissy Spacek... Warren Oates as her father; and all of the less familiar actors but most of all, Terrence Malick, who wrote and directed Badlands. It is clearly his triumph.
It signals the directorial debut of what appears to be a knowledgeable, almost classically precise, important young filmmaker, Terrence Malick.
Terrence Malick's amazing debut feature, Badlands, which basically made the careers of everyone whose name was attached to it.

The film is admirable visually, verbally, psychologically. It took guts for a neophyte film maker still in his twenties to fire two cinematographers before a third gave him what he wanted; yet the result is seamlessly impeccable.

review_content: A film so fascinatingly liberal it almost seems to exist in a different universe.
You feel guilty liking this manipulative pulp, but it somehow grabs and holds onto you.
As a movie Billy Jack is kind of exasperating since there is so much good and bad all mixed together.
The movie has as many causes in it as a year's run of the New Republic. There's not a single contemporary issue, from ecology to gun control, that's not covered.
A little heavy-handed with the message, this film still holds onto the brutality of the revenge style established in Born Losers.
Billy Jack f*%k yea!
Lame, self indulgent when released in 1971, but even more so now.
... when peaceful protest is met with guns and brutality, Billy kicks ass as a one-man-army of poetic justice.
Billy Jack is the nicest surprise of the year, and my own feeling is that it ranks among the top half-dozen American films so far in 1971.
The film works in spite of itself, in primitive fashion and because its locale, its odd mixture of pros and real local nonprofessional talents
While it's still a bit racy, it's tame enough now for the whole family!
Those who are patient and forgiving enough are going to be awarded with good acting, sharp dialogue and effective black humour.
This film deserves the cult status it has among more serious science fiction fans.
It is offensive, but it is also damn funny, and my sense of humor wins out in the end.
Bizarre late-70's sci-fi weirdness. With Don Johnson!
A grungy, odd cult film.
The good ideas are marred by awkwardness; the terrible ideas are redeemed somewhat by being, at least, unpredictable.
Conceptually interesting, with one of the all-time great movie endings.
Jones's cameo during an open-air movie theater sequence is by far the most cinematic moment of this 1975 cult classic for boys who hate women.
(No quote available.)
"nifty little cult flick"
Despite memorable main characters, a half-decent take on an overused premise, and unforgettable scenes, the film's attitude and political stance haven't aged with grace.

Set on a desert landscape a while after a nuclear holocaust, the film is about a young man, played by Don Johnson, who has a telepathic bond with a dog, the latter basically being the smarter of the two. He helps the dog find food and the dog helps him sn
It's got a unique... well, I was about to say charm, but the movie's last scene doesn't quite let me get away with that.
Jones' debut as a director nevertheless has a distinctive tang, as affably unprincipled as the series of villains he played for Sam Peckinpah.
A Boy and His Dog has won a cult following of its own for its offbeat, sardonic look into the future.
In spite of some clever ideas and a few well-wrought images, it seems too schematic and its satire too blunt.
The savage wasteland is believably captured, but a so-so movie completely goes off the rails once the action moves to an underground society.
If it's weirdness that you're after, this cult film goes the whole nine yards.
An unexpected triumph.
How bad is this infamous 1980 musical mega-dud? So bad that it stars not, one, not two, but three people who can't sing, dance or act.
Points for not calling it "The Village People Movie" -- but not many.
An absolute train wreck of a movie, but viewed as a sort of fevered dream, some hilariously campy moments!
The unevenness of the acting comes as a kind of blessing, though, since the rest of the movie is so thoroughly homogenized.
A wretchedly sub-standard score from Jacques Morali and production numbers of exceptional tackiness round things off.
It's tough to believe any movie that opens with Steve Guttenberg dancing on rollerskates could actually get worse from there, but it does -- and in such spectacular fashion!
This botched affair... goes absolutely nowhere and failed to cause much of a stir with moviegoers who, by the time of its release, were jumping on the disco backlash bandwagon.
The Village People, along with ex-Olympic decathlon champion Bruce Jenner, have a long way to go in the acting stakes.
Please DO stop the music! A '70s disco holdover.

Pretty poor, but the enjoyable level of kitsch places it above the other musical turkeys of the era, all of which are far more painful to endure (Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band, Xanadu, The Apple).
Very, very disappointing Stuart Gordon effort
Rarely do you see a film that combines graphic sex and cannibal gore to such grisly effect, and that may be a good thing, but it's important to praise a movie for what it gets right.
Not as freaky as it sounds.
A good Combs/Gordon effort.
A slim tale of redemption and survival, with excitable acting that practically transforms the effort into 3-D, but the macabre essentials are provided with skill by the helmer.
